qas.question: What is the primary consideration for determining if projects may be carried out in areas with endangered species?

answers.text: whether a listed species will be harmed by the action and, if so, how the harm can be minimized

qas.question: If a species may be harmed, who holds final say on whether the project may proceed?
How many members are on the ad hoc panel that allows project exemptions for cases where a species may harmed?
How many votes must be in favor of the exemption in order to award the exemption?
What is one specific requirement regarding the make-up of the exmeption panel?

answers.text: at least one appointee from the state where the project is to occur

qas.question: Who does the Endangered Species Committee get an exemption from?
How many members must vote against the exemption?
How many members must a project agency have?
What do project agencies vote on?

plausible_answers.text: the project agency can seek an exemption

qas.question: What happens if the harm can be minimized?

context: The question to be answered is <a0_0>whether a listed species will be harmed by the action and, if so, how the harm can be minimized<a0_0/>. If harm cannot be avoided, <b9_0>the <b5_0>project agency<b5_0/> can seek an exemption<b9_0/> from <a1_0>the Endangered Species Committee<a1_0/>, an ad hoc panel composed of members from the executive branch and <a4_0>at least one appointee from the state where the project is to occur<a4_0/>. <a3_0><b6_0>Five<b6_0/><a3_0/> of the <a2_0><b7_0>seven<b7_0/><a2_0/> committee members must vote for <b8_0>the exemption<b8_0/> to allow taking (to harass, harm, pursue, hunt, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect, or significant habitat modification, or to attempt to engage in any such conduct) of listed species.
